Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose \u201cOne-Shot Two-Hop Quantum Teleportation via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic\u2010Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\nExplanation and conceptual layout:\n\n\u2013 Nodes and photons:\n  \u2022 Node A (Alice) holds an unknown qubit photon 0 plus one half (photon 1) of Bell pair S1.\n  \u2022 Node B (Repeater) holds the other half (photon 2) of S1 and one half (photon 3) of a second Bell pair S2.\n  \u2022 Node C (Charlie) holds the other half (photon 4) of S2.\n\n\u2013 Resource generation:\n  \u2022 Source S1 probabilistically emits entangled pair (1\u21942).\n  \u2022 Source S2 probabilistically emits entangled pair (3\u21944).\n  \u2022 A separate single\u2010photon source prepares the unknown qubit 0.\n\n\u2013 Measurement at Node B:\n  \u2022 Photons 2 and 3 (one from each Bell pair) together with the unknown 0 all enter a single reconfigurable 4-mode linear-optics interferometer implemented via an optical metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The metasurface is designed to effect the two successive Bell projections (0\u22972 and 2\u22973) simultaneously as one 4-photon joint measurement.  \n  \u2022 Four ancilla output modes are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors. A single specific detection pattern heralds that 0 has been teleported to 4 in Node C, without any intermediate feed-forward.\n\n\u2013 Roles of photonic crystals:\n  \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal network on chip implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive simultaneous and in the correct spatial modes onto the metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The photonic crystal also filters out spurious sidebands and ensures pure single-mode operation, critical for high\u2010fidelity multi-photon interference.\n\n\u2013 Why it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates fusing multiple entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one static joint measurement, reducing the need for active switching or classical communication.  \n  \u2022 Leverages metasurfaces for complex multi-photon projections and photonic crystals for integrated timing/control\u2014two rapidly advancing photonic platforms.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended: three-hop teleportation (six-photon joint measurement), star\u2010topologies, or network repeater nodes with higher fan-out.  \n\nThis target focuses on the quantum-network task of teleportation over two segments in one \u201cshot,\u201d avoiding forbidden state generation tasks, and is well matched to pytheus\u2019s ability to optimize linear-optics networks with probabilistic sources and ancilla detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the same target as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two-Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network,\u201d merging two successive Bell swaps into one four-photon joint measurement to teleport across two segments in one shot. The use of a metasurface and photonic-crystal routing amounts to an implementation detail, not a new network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core idea of compressing two sequential Bell measurements into a single four-photon joint measurement for two-hop teleportation has already been proposed and must be substantively extended (e.g. by adding a genuinely new causal structure, higher-order topological feature, or novel resource type) to be considered for PRL.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Explanation:\nWe propose \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Quantum Teleportation via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic\u2010Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\nLayout and Roles:\n \u2022 Photon 0: unknown qubit from a single-photon emitter (Alice\u2019s input).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S1: probabilistic source emits photons 1\u21942.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S2: probabilistic source emits photons 3\u21944.  \n \u2022 Node B (Repeater) collects photons 0,2,3,1 into a single metasurface\u2010based 4-port interferometer which enacts the combined Bell-measurement on (0,1) and (2,3) simultaneously.  \n \u2022 Node C (Charlie) holds photon 4 as the teleported output.\n\nPhotonic\u2010Crystal Functions:\n \u2022 Implements on-chip static delay lines and wavelength\u2010selective routing so that photons 0,1,2,3 arrive simultaneously in the correct spatial modes at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering and single-mode purity essential for high-visibility four-photon interference.\n\nMetasurface Measurement:\n \u2022 A designed 4-mode linear\u2010optics network on an optical metasurface performs the joint projection onto the product of two Bell bases in one step.  \n \u2022 Four output modes of this metasurface are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors. A single heralding pattern signals successful two-hop teleportation of 0\u21924 with known Pauli frame (to be corrected offline or tracked).\n\nWhy It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable:\n \u2022 Eliminates intermediate feed\u2010forward and classical communication in multi-hop teleportation by compressing the entire repeater step into one joint-measurement node.  \n \u2022 Opens the door to \u201cone-shot\u201d N-hop teleportation by scaling the metasurface to more modes and pairs.  \n \u2022 Brings together two cutting-edge photonic platforms: metasurfaces for complex multi-photon unitary design and photonic crystals for on-chip timing and routing.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n```\n{\n  description: \"One\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Teleportation via Metasurface Multiport\",\n  foldername: \"one_shot_two_hop_teleport\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  samples: 10,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  single_emitters: [0],           # photon 0 = unknown qubit\n  removed_connections: [],        # default pair\u2010source routing is fine\n  in_nodes: [],                   # all sources feed into the metasurface\n  anc_detectors: [0,1,2,3],       # metasurface outputs that are measured\n  out_nodes: [4]                  # photon 4 is the teleported output\n}\n```\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal merely repackages the existing one\u2010shot two\u2010hop entanglement swap/teleportation primitive\u2014already described in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network\u201d\u2014and adds only platform-specific layers (metasurface, photonic\u2010crystal routing).     "output": "We propose a \u201cTeleportation Switchboard\u201d\u2014a single, static linear-optics node that, by post-selection, teleports an unknown qubit to one of two receivers (Bob or Charlie) without any active feed-forward, exploiting an optical metasurface for the multi\u2010photon joint measurement and a dielectric photonic\u2010crystal chip for passive spectral/time\u2010bin routing.\n\nExplanation and sketch:\n\n  1. Resources & Labels  \n     \u2022 Unknown qubit: photon 0, prepared by a single-photon emitter at Alice.  \n     \u2022 Bell pair S1: photons 1\u21942 (Alice \u2194 Bob).  \n     \u2022 Bell pair S2: photons 3\u21944 (Alice \u2194 Charlie).  \n     \u2022 Receivers hold photons 2 (Bob) and 4 (Charlie).  \n\n  2. Goal  \n     Alice wants to teleport her unknown qubit (0) to *either* Bob or Charlie, with the choice \u201cmade by the measurement outcome itself.\u201d  Two distinct heralding patterns tell \u201cteleported to Bob\u201d vs. \u201cteleported to Charlie.\u201d  \n\n  3. Photonic\u2010Crystal Preprocessing  \n     \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal chip implements two tasks in one:  \n       \u2013 Static delay lines so that photons 0,1,3 arrive simultaneously.  \n       \u2013 Wavelength/time-bin demultiplexing so that different spectral channels map to the Bob- vs. Charlie-branch modes of the metasurface.  \n\n  4. Metasurface Multiport Measurement  \n     \u2022 A single 6\u00d76 metasurface interferometer mixes Alice\u2019s three photons (0,1,3) with three vacuum ancilla modes.  \n     \u2022 Six outputs are monitored by number-resolving detectors.  \n     \u2022 Two specific click\u2010patterns project {0,1} onto the Bell basis *and* {0,3} onto the Bell basis in one shot:  \n       \u2013 Pattern \u201cP_B\u201d heralds that \u03c1\u2080 has been teleported to photon 2 (Bob).  \n       \u2013 Pattern \u201cP_C\u201d heralds that \u03c1\u2080 has been teleported to photon 4 (Charlie).  \n     \u2022 No active routing or fast electronics is needed\u2014Alice just waits for either P_B or P_C.  \n\n  5. Why It\u2019s New & Generalizable  \n     \u2022 Conventional multi-hop or multi-receiver teleportation always requires active feed-forward and fast switching. Here the *measurement outcome alone* both signals and effects the routing.  \n     \u2022 Merges two cutting-edge platforms: metasurfaces for high-order multi-photon mixing, and photonic crystals for passive, on-chip temporal/spectral control.  \n     \u2022 Fully \u201cstatic\u201d (post\u2010selected) protocol\u2014ideal for Pytheus.  \n     \u2022 Natural extensions: N-destination teleportation switchboard (N+1-photon joint measurement), star networks, or hierarchical routing trees.  \n\nPytheus configuration skeleton:\n\n{'description': 'Teleportation switchboard to Bob or Charlie via metasurface+photonic\u2010crystal routing',  \n 'foldername': 'teleport_switch',  \n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n 'edges_tried': 40,  \n 'ftol': 1e-6,  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'num_anc': 6,               # six ancilla detectors at metasurface outputs  \n 'num_pre': 1,  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'samples': 10,  \n 'imaginary': False,  \n 'safe_hist': True,  \n 'number_resolving': True,  \n 'single_emitters': [0],     # photon 0 = unknown qubit  \n 'removed_connections': [],  # allow standard pair-source routing  \n 'in_nodes': [],             # Alice\u2019s three photons + vacuum modes feed the metasurface  \n 'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3,4,5], # all six metasurface outputs are measured  \n 'out_nodes': [2,4]          # photon 2 (Bob) or 4 (Charlie) is the teleported qubit  \n}\n\nTarget quantum (abstractly):  \n\u2013 If detectors click pattern P_B then Alice\u2019s input \u03c1\u2080 appears on out_node 2.  \n\u2013 If detectors click pattern P_C then \u03c1\u2080 appears on out_node 4.  \n\nAll is done with:  \n\u2022 Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources (1-2, 3-4)  \n\u2022 One single-photon unknown qubit source (0)  \n\u2022 One static metasurface multiport  \n\u2022 Passive photonic\u2010crystal routing/delay  \n\u2022 Number resolving detectors and post-selection  \n\nThis sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (no feedback control, all linear optics + photon counting) and opens up a new primitive\u2014post-selected quantum routing/switching in a multi-receiver teleportation network."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Phase-Matching Quantum Key Distribution without Intensity Modulation\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Mitigation of crosstalk and noise in multicore fiber on quantum\n  communication\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Maximal coin-walker entanglement in a ballistic quantum walk\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': Concept and Roles:\n  \u2022 Photon 0: unknown qubit (single-photon emitter at Alice).  \n  \u2022 Bell pair S1: probabilistic source emits photons 1\u21942.  \n  \u2022 Bell pair S2: probabilistic source emits photons 3\u21944.  \n  \u2022 Node B (Repeater): collects photons 0,1,2,3 into a single metasurface-based 4-mode interferometer that enacts the combined Bell projections on (0,1) and (2,3) in one shot.  \n  \u2022 Node C (Charlie): holds photon 4 as teleported output.\n\n2. Photonic-Crystal Functions:\n  \u2022 Implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that photons 0\u20133 arrive simultaneously into the metasurface modes.  \n  \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering and single-mode purity for high-visibility four-photon interference.\n\n3. Metasurface Joint Measurement:\n  \u2022 A custom optical metasurface executes a 4\u00d74 unitary mixing network corresponding to two fused Bell measurements.  \n  \u2022 Four output modes are monitored by number-resolving detectors; one specific heralding pattern signals successful two-hop teleportation from 0\u21924 (with known Pauli frame for offline correction).\n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable:\n  \u2022 Compresses two sequential entanglement-swapping steps into one static joint measurement, eliminating active switching and classical communication between hops.  \n  \u2022 Demonstrates high-order photonic metasurface capabilities in quantum-network primitives.  \n  \u2022 Photonic crystals integrate timing, routing, and filtering on-chip\u2014showcasing two emerging photonic platforms in tandem.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended to N-hop \u201cone-shot\u201d teleportation or repeater networks with more segments by scaling the metasurface to more modes.\n\n5.     "output": "Thought:\n Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201coptical metasurfaces\u201d and \u201cdielectric photonic crystal\u201d into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network target:\n   1. One\u2010shot two\u2010hop teleportation: fuse two sequential Bell\u2010measurements into a single four-photon joint measurement on a metasurface, with photonic-crystal waveguides providing fixed delays and spectral routing.\n   2. Multi-receiver teleportation switchboard: Alice broadcasts an unknown qubit onto one of N Bobs by a single metasurface multiport measurement, while a photonic crystal chip implements N-channel wavelength multiplexing.\n   3. Reconfigurable entanglement router: a metasurface\u2013photonic-crystal chip at the center of a four-node square can be statically tuned to swap either the nearest neighbors (A\u2013B & C\u2013D) or the diagonals (A\u2013D & B\u2013C).\n\n Step 2: Quick novelty & Pytheus feasibility:\n   1. Two-hop teleport is absent from existing list, uses only probabilistic sources + single-photon emitter + static multiport + ancilla detectors, no feedback \u2192 fully Pytheus-compatible.\n   2. Multi-receiver needs high-photon-number joint measurement, feasible only for very small N.\n   3. Router is just two separate swapping patterns, less unified as a novel primitive.\n\n Step 3: Select (1): One\u2010shot two\u2010hop teleportation.\n\n Step 4: Novelty: Compresses two sequential entanglement-swapping (teleportation) steps into one static four-photon joint measurement, eliminating intermediate classical feed-forward and active switching. Demonstrates the power of metasurfaces for high-order photon mixing alongside photonic-crystal routing.\n\n Step 5: Feasibility: Uses only linear optics with probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one single-photon emitter (unknown qubit), a single static interferometer (optical metasurface), number-resolving detectors, and fixed delays/spectral filters in a photonic-crystal chip\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nWe propose \u201cOne-Shot Two-Hop Quantum Teleportation via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic-Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nIn a standard two-hop teleportation (A\u2192B then B\u2192C), you perform two sequential Bell measurements and send classical outcomes forward. Here we fuse both Bell projections into a single static four-photon joint measurement implemented on an optical metasurface, and use a dielectric photonic-crystal network for on-chip delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive in phase.\n\nNodes & Photons:\n \u2022 Alice (A) holds photon 0 in an unknown qubit state |\u03c8\u27e9 (single-photon emitter) and photon 1 (half of Bell pair S\u2081).  \n \u2022 Repeater (B) holds photon 2 (the other half of S\u2081) and photon 3 (half of Bell pair S\u2082).  \n \u2022 Charlie (C) holds photon 4 (the other half of S\u2082).\n\nResources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits 1\u21942; S\u2082 emits 3\u21944 probabilistically.  \n \u2022 Photon 0 is the unknown input from a single-photon source.  \n \u2022 Photonic-crystal waveguides implement fixed delays and tight spectral filtering so that 0\u20133 arrive simultaneously onto the metasurface.\n\nMetasurface Measurement:\n \u2022 A 4-mode linear-optics network on an optical metasurface effects the two Bell projections (0\u22971 and 2\u22973) simultaneously as one joint measurement.  \n \u2022 Its four output modes feed number-resolving detectors. A single heralding pattern indicates that |\u03c8\u27e9 has been teleported from 0\u21924 (with known Pauli frame) in one shot.\n\nWhy It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable:\n \u2022 Eliminates intermediate classical communication and switching\u2014both heralding and output correction can be handled offline.  \n \u2022 Showcases metasurfaces for high-order multi-photon operations and photonic crystals for integrated timing/routing.  \n \u2022 Directly extensible to \u201cone-shot N-hop\u201d teleporters (use a 2N-photon joint measurement on a metasurface) or chain-topologies.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n```python\n{\n  'description': 'One-Shot Two-Hop Teleportation via Metasurface Multiport',\n  'foldername': 'one_shot_two_hop_teleport',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # detectors on the metasurface outputs\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'number_resolving': True,\n  'single_emitters': [0],       # photon 0 is the unknown qubit\n  'removed_connections': [],    # standard Bell-pair routing is allowed\n  'in_nodes': [],               # sources feed directly into the metasurface\n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],   # metasurface output modes\n  'out_nodes': [4]              # photon 4 is the teleported output\n}\n```\nThis target is a pure quantum-network primitive (two-hop teleportation) that Pytheus can optimize as a static linear-optics + ancilla-detection experiment, and it directly leverages both optical metasurfaces and dielectric photonic-crystal routing."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Three-Node Entanglement Router Optimizing Genuine Tripartite Mutual Information\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a static photonic linear-optical network in Pytheus\u2014comprising three SPDC pair sources, a tunable three-mode interferometer, and heralding ancilla detectors\u2014to variationally extremize the genuine tripartite mutual information I\u2083(A;B;C) among remote modes A, B, and C. A classical optimizer adjusts interferometer phases to maximize (or minimize) I\u2083(A;B;C) as the sole cost function, thereby targeting non-trivial entanglement monogamy without prescribing any specific quantum state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Only Entanglement Swapping via a Discrete Squeezed-Reservoir\n\nAbstract: We introduce a purely network-level primitive in which two SPDC sources generate entangled pairs AB (modes 1\u20132) and BC (modes 3\u20134), and a third SPDC source at Bob produces a \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u201d Bell pair (modes 5\u20136) that is weakly coupled via beam splitters to Bob\u2019s system modes 2 and 3. By performing photon-counting only on the ancilla modes and conditioning on coincident clicks, Alice\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s remote modes 1 and 4 are projected onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014effecting entanglement swapping without ever measuring Bob\u2019s system qubits and preserving local memory for subsequent quantum network operations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Amplitude-Damping Entanglement Router Certified by Tomographic Witnesses\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe implement a fully static, loss-controlled quantum router that uses two SPDC Bell-pair sources and an amplitude-damping switch\u2014heralded by ancilla photon clicks\u2014to branch-selectively route entanglement from source A either to node B or C without dynamic feedback or forbidden elements. End-to-end tomography at the chosen node measures the three projector outcomes specified for the selected entanglement witness (the explicit target quantum set), thereby certifying entanglement only in the routed branch.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nBoundary-Scaling Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer for Toric-Code Patches  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a static linear-optical circuit\u2014the Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer with Boundary-Scaling\u2014that simultaneously measures all four-body Z stabilizers of an arbitrary connected toric-code plaquette patch using a shared pool of ancilla photons, such that the total ancilla detectors (or photons) scale with the patch\u2019s perimeter rather than its area. By mapping each polarization-encoded Bell state onto a unique two-click pattern across six threshold detectors, our design explicitly targets and breaks the 50% success bound of conventional linear-optics Bell analyzers.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIntegrated Photonic Quantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target \u201cQuantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities\u201d by coherently splitting an unknown single-photon qubit at node A and teleporting it, via two independent probabilistic entangled-pair sources and synchronized on-chip delay loops, onto two remote outputs at nodes B and C. Post-selecting a fixed Bell outcome in each Bell-state measurement and employing only passive 50:50 beam splitters, fixed delay cavities, ancilla detectors, and single-photon emitters realizes a genuine quantum routing primitive that maps |\u03c8\u27e9\u2090 \u2192 (|\u03c8\u27e9\u1d66 + |\u03c8\u27e9\ud835\udcb8)/\u221a2 without feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Testing Non-Commutativity of Dissipative Lindblad Channels via Entanglement Swapping\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static, purely linear-optical network using two SPDC Bell-pair sources, amplitude- and phase-damping beam-splitter ancillas, and a post-selected Bell-state measurement to swap entanglement through the two Lindblad maps L\u2081 (amplitude damping) and L\u2082 (phase damping) in both orders. By heralding the \u03a6\u207a outcome and comparing A\u2013D output fidelities under L\u2081\u2218L\u2082 versus L\u2082\u2218L\u2081, we directly quantify the target non-zero commutator [L\u2081,L\u2082], thus probing the non-commutativity of Markovian dissipative channels.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Passive HOM-Filtered Entanglement Swapping Repeater for Remote Qubits A and D\n\nAbstract: We present a static, linear-optical repeater node that embeds a Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel multi-pair suppression filter into the four-mode Bell-state measurement interferometer to passively enact error-filtered entanglement swapping. Conditioned on two ancillary detector clicks, this scheme directly projects the target qubits A and D into a high-fidelity Bell state while suppressing unwanted double-pair emissions from probabilistic photon-pair sources.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Static Linear-Optical Analyzer for Four-Qubit Cluster-Basis Discrimination\n\nMini-abstract: We present a fully static, post-selected linear-optical module targeting the unambiguous discrimination of all four orthogonal four-qubit linear-cluster basis states. By alternating this primitive with single-qubit \u03c3\u2093 rotations, we Trotterize the 1D Rydberg Hamiltonian H_Ryd = \u03a9\u2211_i\u03c3\u2093^i + V\u2211_{\u27e8i,j\u27e9}n_i n_j with blockade radius spanning three sites, thus emulating the nonlinear many-body Rydberg blockade measurement in a photonic network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nDirectional Entanglement Swapping with Simulated Skin and Mott Photon\u2010Blockade Effects\n\nAbstract:\nWe propose a three\u2010site entanglement\u2010swapping chain that teleports a Bell state from Alice ([0]) to Bob ([1]) using three probabilistic SPDC sources ([2,3,4]), with non\u2010Hermitian \u201cskin\u201d localization enforced by removing all backward source\u2013detector links and an on\u2010site Mott\u2010like photon blockade realized by heralding on the central ancilla ([6]). By configuring Pythues to optimize the internal beam\u2010splitter network under these directional and blockade constraints, we can sweep the teleportation fidelity of the target \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 state between a uniform \u201csuperfluid\u201d regime and a gapped, localized \u201cMott\u201d regime within a single linear\u2010optical setup.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Sequential Non-Demolition Qutrit Measurement Network for KCBS Contextuality via Tunable Ancilla Coupling\n\nMini-abstract: We target a sequential nondestructive qutrit measurement network for KCBS contextuality with tunable ultrastrong-coupling ancillas, implementing the five-node pentagon test by entangling a single-photon qutrit with five ancilla photons through beam splitters of adjustable reflectivity R\u2081\u2026R\u2085. In a single measurement this three-copy Schur transform directly yields the second and third R\u00e9nyi moments, Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b2] and Tr[\u03c1_A\u00b3], thereby fully characterizing the entanglement spectrum of the target subsystem A.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Three-Node Linear-Optical Violation of the Bilocality Inequality\n\nAbstract: We propose a bilocality-test network in which two independent probabilistic entangled-photon-pair sources feed a static partial Bell-state analyzer at a central node B, while peripheral nodes A and C perform fixed-basis single-qubit measurements conditioned on ancilla-heralded joint outcomes at B. A single specific detection pattern heralds that 0 has been teleported to 4 in Node C, without any intermediate feed-forward.\n\n\u2013 Roles of photonic crystals:\n  \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal network on chip implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive simultaneous and in the correct spatial modes onto the metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The photonic crystal also filters out spurious sidebands and ensures pure single-mode operation, critical for high\u2010fidelity multi-photon interference.\n\n\u2013 Why it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates fusing multiple entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one static joint measurement, reducing the need for active switching or classical communication.  \n  \u2022 Leverages metasurfaces for complex multi-photon projections and photonic crystals for integrated timing/control\u2014two rapidly advancing photonic platforms.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended: three-hop teleportation (six-photon joint measurement), star\u2010topologies, or network repeater nodes with higher fan-out.  \n\nThis target focuses on the quantum-network task of teleportation over two segments in one \u201cshot,\u201d avoiding forbidden state generation tasks, and is well matched to pytheus\u2019s ability to optimize linear-optics networks with probabilistic sources and ancilla detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the same target as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two-Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network,\u201d merging two successive Bell swaps into one four-photon joint measurement to teleport across two segments in one shot. The use of a metasurface and photonic-crystal routing amounts to an implementation detail, not a new network primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core idea of compressing two sequential Bell measurements into a single four-photon joint measurement for two-hop teleportation has already been proposed and must be substantively extended (e.g. by adding a genuinely new causal structure, higher-order topological feature, or novel resource type) to be considered for PRL.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Explanation:\nWe propose \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Quantum Teleportation via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic\u2010Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\nLayout and Roles:\n \u2022 Photon 0: unknown qubit from a single-photon emitter (Alice\u2019s input).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S1: probabilistic source emits photons 1\u21942.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S2: probabilistic source emits photons 3\u21944.  \n \u2022 Node B (Repeater) collects photons 0,2,3,1 into a single metasurface\u2010based 4-port interferometer which enacts the combined Bell-measurement on (0,1) and (2,3) simultaneously.  \n \u2022 Node C (Charlie) holds photon 4 as the teleported output.\n\nPhotonic\u2010Crystal Functions:\n \u2022 Implements on-chip static delay lines and wavelength\u2010selective routing so that photons 0,1,2,3 arrive simultaneously in the correct spatial modes at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering and single-mode purity essential for high-visibility four-photon interference.\n\nMetasurface Measurement:\n \u2022 A designed 4-mode linear\u2010optics network on an optical metasurface performs the joint projection onto the product of two Bell bases in one step.  \n \u2022 Four output modes of this metasurface are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors. A single heralding pattern signals successful two-hop teleportation of 0\u21924 with known Pauli frame (to be corrected offline or tracked).\n\nWhy It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable:\n \u2022 Eliminates intermediate feed\u2010forward and classical communication in multi-hop teleportation by compressing the entire repeater step into one joint-measurement node.  \n \u2022 Opens the door to \u201cone-shot\u201d N-hop teleportation by scaling the metasurface to more modes and pairs.  \n \u2022 Brings together two cutting-edge photonic platforms: metasurfaces for complex multi-photon unitary design and photonic crystals for on-chip timing and routing.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n```\n{\n  description: \"One\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Teleportation via Metasurface Multiport\",\n  foldername: \"one_shot_two_hop_teleport\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  samples: 10,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  single_emitters: [0],           # photon 0 = unknown qubit\n  removed_connections: [],        # default pair\u2010source routing is fine\n  in_nodes: [],                   # all sources feed into the metasurface\n  anc_detectors: [0,1,2,3],       # metasurface outputs that are measured\n  out_nodes: [4]                  # photon 4 is the teleported output\n}\n```\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal merely repackages the existing one\u2010shot two\u2010hop entanglement swap/teleportation primitive\u2014already described in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network\u201d\u2014and adds only platform-specific layers (metasurface, photonic\u2010crystal routing). It does not introduce a new network primitive, causal structure, or resource beyond a trivial implementation detail.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The core idea of compressing two sequential Bell measurements into a single four\u2010photon joint measurement for two\u2010hop teleportation has already been proposed. To achieve PRL\u2010level novelty, the scheme must introduce a genuinely new quantum\u2010network primitive (e.g. novel resource type, higher\u2010order topology, or causal superposition) rather than an implementation upgrade.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose \u201cOne-Shot Two-Hop Quantum Teleportation via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic-Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\n1. Concept and Roles:\n  \u2022 Photon 0: unknown qubit (single-photon emitter at Alice).  \n  \u2022 Bell pair S1: probabilistic source emits photons 1\u21942.  \n  \u2022 Bell pair S2: probabilistic source emits photons 3\u21944.  \n  \u2022 Node B (Repeater): collects photons 0,1,2,3 into a single metasurface-based 4-mode interferometer that enacts the combined Bell projections on (0,1) and (2,3) in one shot.  \n  \u2022 Node C (Charlie): holds photon 4 as teleported output.\n\n2. Photonic-Crystal Functions:\n  \u2022 Implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that photons 0\u20133 arrive simultaneously into the metasurface modes.  \n  \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering and single-mode purity for high-visibility four-photon interference.\n\n3. Metasurface Joint Measurement:\n  \u2022 A custom optical metasurface executes a 4\u00d74 unitary mixing network corresponding to two fused Bell measurements.  \n  \u2022 Four output modes are monitored by number-resolving detectors; one specific heralding pattern signals successful two-hop teleportation from 0\u21924 (with known Pauli frame for offline correction).\n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable:\n  \u2022 Compresses two sequential entanglement-swapping steps into one static joint measurement, eliminating active switching and classical communication between hops.  \n  \u2022 Demonstrates high-order photonic metasurface capabilities in quantum-network primitives.  \n  \u2022 Photonic crystals integrate timing, routing, and filtering on-chip\u2014showcasing two emerging photonic platforms in tandem.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended to N-hop \u201cone-shot\u201d teleportation or repeater networks with more segments by scaling the metasurface to more modes.\n\n5. Pytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n{'description': 'One-Shot Two-Hop Teleportation via Metasurface Multiport',  \n 'foldername': 'one_shot_two_hop_teleport',  \n 'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n 'edges_tried': 30,  \n 'ftol': 1e-6,  \n 'loss_func': 'cr',  \n 'num_anc': 4,                      # four ancilla detectors at metasurface outputs  \n 'num_pre': 1,  \n 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n 'samples': 10,  \n 'imaginary': False,  \n 'safe_hist': True,  \n 'number_resolving': True,  \n 'single_emitters': [0],           # photon 0 = unknown qubit  \n 'removed_connections': [],        # allow standard pair-source routing  \n 'in_nodes': [],                   # all sources feed into metasurface  \n 'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],       # detect metasurface outputs  \n 'out_nodes': [4]                  # photon 4 is teleported output  \n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cone\u2010shot two\u2010hop teleportation\u201d exactly mirrors the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network,\u201d fusing two Bell\u2010swap steps into a single four\u2010photon joint measurement. Using a metasurface and photonic\u2010crystal routing is merely an implementation detail\u2014not a new network primitive or causal feature.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This idea does not introduce a fundamentally new quantum\u2010network target beyond the already proposed one\u2010shot two\u2010hop entanglement swap. To be novel at the PRL level, the scheme must add a new resource type, nontrivial causal or topological structure, or a genuinely unexplored measurement primitive rather than just swapping the photonic platform.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: We propose \u201cOne-Shot Two-Hop Quantum Teleportation via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic-Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\nExplanation:\nIn a standard two-hop teleportation (A\u2192B then B\u2192C), you perform two sequential Bell measurements and send classical outcomes forward. Here we fuse both Bell projections into a single static four-photon joint measurement implemented on an optical metasurface, and use a dielectric photonic-crystal network for on-chip delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive in phase.\n\nNodes & Photons:\n \u2022 Alice (A) holds photon 0 in an unknown qubit state |\u03c8\u27e9 (single-photon emitter) and photon 1 (half of Bell pair S\u2081).  \n \u2022 Repeater (B) holds photon 2 (the other half of S\u2081) and photon 3 (half of Bell pair S\u2082).  \n \u2022 Charlie (C) holds photon 4 (the other half of S\u2082).\n\nResources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits 1\u21942; S\u2082 emits 3\u21944 probabilistically.  \n \u2022 Photon 0 is the unknown input from a single-photon source.  \n \u2022 Photonic-crystal waveguides implement fixed delays and tight spectral filtering so that 0\u20133 arrive simultaneously onto the metasurface.\n\nMetasurface Measurement:\n \u2022 A 4-mode linear-optics network on an optical metasurface effects the two Bell projections (0\u22971 and 2\u22973) simultaneously as one joint measurement.  \n \u2022 Its four output modes feed number-resolving detectors. A single heralding pattern indicates that |\u03c8\u27e9 has been teleported from 0\u21924 (with known Pauli frame) in one shot.\n\nWhy It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable:\n \u2022 Eliminates intermediate classical communication and switching\u2014both heralding and output correction can be handled offline.  \n \u2022 Showcases metasurfaces for high-order multi-photon operations and photonic crystals for integrated timing/routing.  \n \u2022 Directly extensible to \u201cone-shot N-hop\u201d teleporters (use a 2N-photon joint measurement on a metasurface) or chain-topologies.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n```python\n{\n  'description': 'One-Shot Two-Hop Teleportation via Metasurface Multiport',\n  'foldername': 'one_shot_two_hop_teleport',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 30,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,                 # detectors on the metasurface outputs\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 10,\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'number_resolving': True,\n  'single_emitters': [0],       # photon 0 is the unknown qubit\n  'removed_connections': [],    # standard Bell-pair routing is allowed\n  'in_nodes': [],               # sources feed directly into the metasurface\n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],   # metasurface output modes\n  'out_nodes': [4]              # photon 4 is the teleported output\n}\n```\nThis target is a pure quantum-network primitive (two-hop teleportation) that Pytheus can optimize as a static linear-optics + ancilla-detection experiment, and it directly leverages both optical metasurfaces and dielectric photonic-crystal routing.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The core quantum-network primitive\u2014compressing two sequential Bell swaps (or teleportation hops) into a single four-photon joint measurement\u2014has already been proposed in the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne-Shot Two-Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network.\u201d Merely swapping in a metasurface and photonic-crystal routing does not constitute a new network primitive or causal/topological feature.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This idea duplicates the one-shot two-hop entanglement-swap/teleportation primitive already in the ensemble list.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Three-Node Entanglement Router Optimizing Genuine Tripartite Mutual Information\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a static photonic linear-optical network in Pytheus\u2014comprising three SPDC pair sources, a tunable three-mode interferometer, and heralding ancilla detectors\u2014to variationally extremize the genuine tripartite mutual information I\u2083(A;B;C) among remote modes A, B, and C. A classical optimizer adjusts interferometer phases to maximize (or minimize) I\u2083(A;B;C) as the sole cost function, thereby targeting non-trivial entanglement monogamy without prescribing any specific quantum state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Only Entanglement Swapping via a Discrete Squeezed-Reservoir\n\nAbstract: We introduce a purely network-level primitive in which two SPDC sources generate entangled pairs AB (modes 1\u20132) and BC (modes 3\u20134), and a third SPDC source at Bob produces a \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u201d Bell pair (modes 5\u20136) that is weakly coupled via beam splitters to Bob\u2019s system modes 2 and 3. By performing photon-counting only on the ancilla modes and conditioning on coincident clicks, Alice\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s remote modes 1 and 4 are projected onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014effecting entanglement swapping without ever measuring Bob\u2019s system qubits and preserving local memory for subsequent quantum network operations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Amplitude-Damping Entanglement Router Certified by Tomographic Witnesses\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe implement a fully static, loss-controlled quantum router that uses two SPDC Bell-pair sources and an amplitude-damping switch\u2014heralded by ancilla photon clicks\u2014to branch-selectively route entanglement from source A either to node B or C without dynamic feedback or forbidden elements. End-to-end tomography at the chosen node measures the three projector outcomes specified for the selected entanglement witness (the explicit target quantum set), thereby certifying entanglement only in the routed branch.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nBoundary-Scaling Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer for Toric-Code Patches  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a static linear-optical circuit\u2014the Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer with Boundary-Scaling\u2014that simultaneously measures all four-body Z stabilizers of an arbitrary connected toric-code plaquette patch using a shared pool of ancilla photons, such that the total ancilla detectors (or photons) scale with the patch\u2019s perimeter rather than its area. This yields a high-fidelity Bell pair between Alice and Bob (the explicit target) within PytHeus\u2019s static linear-optical framework, using two SPDC sources and ancilla detectors without any dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Protected Non-Abelian D\u2083 Teleportation Router on a Three-Node Photonic Triangle\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an all-linear-optical experiment that uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources, beam splitters, and a fixed two-photon ancilla fusion measurement to teleport an unknown target qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 from node A onto one of the three network nodes (A, B, or C) while enacting a non-Abelian D\u2083 group operation (120\u00b0 rotation or mirror reflection) on the teleported target. By mapping each polarization-encoded Bell state onto a unique two-click pattern across six threshold detectors, our design explicitly targets and breaks the 50% success bound of conventional linear-optics Bell analyzers.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nHeralded Linear\u2010Optical 1\u21922 QuTrIt Telecloning via Resonance-Dip Multiport Bell Measurement\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose and analyze a fully linear-optical implementation of the first 1\u21922 qutrit telecloner, in which three probabilistic qutrit-entangled photon-pair sources feed a balanced three-mode multiport Bell measurement module synchronized by identical delay-loop \u201cresonators.\u201d Success of the telecloning is unambiguously heralded by a generalized Hong\u2013Ou\u2013Mandel resonance dip in triple-coincidence ancilla detections, conditionally projecting the two receivers into the optimal symmetric clones of the unknown input qutrit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIntegrated Photonic Quantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate the target \u201cQuantum Teleportation Router with On-Chip Delay Cavities\u201d by coherently splitting an unknown single-photon qubit at node A and teleporting it, via two independent probabilistic entangled-pair sources and synchronized on-chip delay loops, onto two remote outputs at nodes B and C. Only the joint triple-coincidence detection at the network\u2019s three output modes reveals the global third-order phase e^{i(\u03c6A+\u03c6B+\u03c6C)}, while any single- or two-loop marginal yields no measurable phase, thereby realizing the targeted higher-order (Massey) topological invariant.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Implementing an Entanglement-Switch Quantum Switch via Photonic-Controlled Superposition of Swap Orders\n\nAbstract: We report a PytHeus-compatible demonstration of the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d in which a single-photon control qubit coherently superposes two entanglement-swapping sequences (B\u2192C\u2192D vs. C\u2192B\u2192D) across four nodes A, B, C, D, thereby distributing a Bell pair |\u03a6\u207a\u27e9 between A and D in an indefinite causal order. A single specific detection pattern heralds that 0 has been teleported to 4 in Node C, without any intermediate feed-forward.\n\n\u2013 Roles of photonic crystals:\n  \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal network on chip implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive simultaneous and in the correct spatial modes onto the metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The photonic crystal also filters out spurious sidebands and ensures pure single-mode operation, critical for high\u2010fidelity multi-photon interference.\n\n\u2013 Why it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates fusing multiple entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one static joint measurement, reducing the need for active switching or classical communication.  \n  \u2022 Leverages metasurfaces for complex multi-photon projections and photonic crystals for integrated timing/control\u2014two rapidly advancing photonic platforms.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended: three-hop teleportation (six-photon joint measurement), star\u2010topologies, or network repeater nodes with higher fan-out.  \n\nThis target focuses on the quantum-network task of teleportation over two segments in one \u201cshot,\u201d avoiding forbidden state generation tasks, and is well matched to pytheus\u2019s ability to optimize linear-optics networks with probabilistic sources and ancilla detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the same target as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two-Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network,\u201d merging two successive Bell swaps into one four-photon joint measurement to teleport across two segments in one shot.     "output": "Thought: The proposed two\u2010receiver teleportation switch via wavelength multiplexing and metasurface routing is effectively the same network primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip,\u201d which already uses two Bell-pair sources and a single joint measurement to teleport an unknown qubit to one of two Bobs. Merely swapping spatial addressing for spectral demultiplexing does not introduce a new causal structure, resource type, or measurement primitive.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This idea duplicates the dual-destination teleportation switch primitive already proposed. To reach PRL-level novelty, you must add a genuinely new network element\u2014such as indefinite causal order, a higher-dimensional routing resource, or a novel topological/spectral superposition effect\u2014rather than an implementation tweak via metasurfaces or photonic crystals."

A single specific detection pattern heralds that 0 has been teleported to 4 in Node C, without any intermediate feed-forward.\n\n\u2013 Roles of photonic crystals:\n  \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal network on chip implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive simultaneous and in the correct spatial modes onto the metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The photonic crystal also filters out spurious sidebands and ensures pure single-mode operation, critical for high\u2010fidelity multi-photon interference.\n\n\u2013 Why it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates fusing multiple entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one static joint measurement, reducing the need for active switching or classical communication.  \n  \u2022 Leverages metasurfaces for complex multi-photon projections and photonic crystals for integrated timing/control\u2014two rapidly advancing photonic platforms.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended: three-hop teleportation (six-photon joint measurement), star\u2010topologies, or network repeater nodes with higher fan-out.  \n\nThis target focuses on the quantum-network task of teleportation over two segments in one \u201cshot,\u201d avoiding forbidden state generation tasks, and is well matched to pytheus\u2019s ability to optimize linear-optics networks with probabilistic sources and ancilla detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core idea of compressing two sequential Bell measurements into a single four-photon joint measurement for two-hop teleportation has already been proposed and must be substantively extended (e.g. by adding a genuinely new causal structure, higher-order topological feature, or novel resource type) to be considered for PRL.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! Reconfigurable router is interesting but essentially two separate swapping tasks under different settings, less unified than (1).\n\nStep 3: The most promising is (1): One\u2010shot two\u2010hop teleportation via a metasurface multiport and photonic\u2010crystal routing.\n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because it compresses two sequential Bell\u2010measurements with feed-forward into a single static four-photon joint measurement, eliminating the need for intermediate classical communication and active switching. It leverages the rich mode-mixing capabilities of optical metasurfaces alongside photonic\u2010crystal routing and delay to engineer multi-photon interference in one block.\n\nStep 5: It is feasible single metasurface\u2010based 4-port interferometer which enacts the combined Bell-measurement on (0,1) and (2,3) simultaneously.  \n \u2022 Node C (Charlie) holds photon 4 as the teleported output.\n\nPhotonic\u2010Crystal Functions:\n \u2022 Implements on-chip static delay lines and wavelength\u2010selective routing so that photons 0,1,2,3 arrive simultaneously in the correct spatial modes at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering and single-mode purity essential for high-visibility four-photon interference.\n\nMetasurface Measurement:\n \u2022 A designed 4-mode linear\u2010optics network on an optical metasurface performs the joint projection onto the product of two Bell bases in one step.  \n \u2022 Four output modes of this metasurface are monitored by number\u2010resolving detectors.
