Network & Resources  \n \u2022 Nodes A, B, C form a triangle.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 on edge A\u2013B emits photons 1\u21942 at wavelength \u03bb\u2081.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 on B\u2013C emits photons 3\u21944 at \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2083 on C\u2013A emits photons 5\u21946 at \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Control photon 7 is prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter and split into a coherent superposition of three spatial arms |c\u2081\u27e9,|c\u2082\u27e9,|c\u2083\u27e9, routing it to A, B or C.\n\n2. Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements three\u2010way wavelength\u2010demultiplexing (\u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082,\u03bb\u2083), fixed on\u2010chip delays, and narrowband filtering so that the two photons of any chosen Bell pair and the control photon arrive simultaneously and indistinguishably at the metasurface inputs.\n\n3. Metasurface 4-Mode Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes (pair\u2010photon 1, pair\u2010photon 2) + control photon 7 + a vacuum ancilla.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 If the control path was c\u2081 (node A) and D-pattern p\u2081 clicks, the metasurface has effected a Bell\u2010measurement on photons 5&6 (edge C\u2013A), swapping entanglement to yield A\u2013B entangled.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2082 & pattern p\u2082, then B performs the swap on (1&2), entangling B\u2013C.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2083 & pattern p\u2083, then C swaps (3&4), entangling C\u2013A.  \n Because the control photon was in superposition, all three swap\u2010locations are coherently superposed, realizing a genuine triangular\u2010network quantum SWITCH.\n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 Introduces a new quantum\u2010network primitive: superposed choice of which node performs entanglement\u2010swap in a cycle.  \n \u2022 Combines two emerging photonic platforms\u2014metasurfaces for multi-photon unitary design and photonic crystals for passive routing/delay\u2014into a single network operation.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond line\u2010network causal superpositions to a loop topology with three alternatives.  \n \u2022 Extensible to larger graphs (e.g. squares, pentagons) by adding more Bell pairs, control photons, and metasurface ports.\n\n5. Pytheus Configuration Skeleton  \n{\n  'description': 'Superposed\u2010Node Swap on Triangle Network',\n  'foldername': 'triangle_superposition_swap',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,                   # detectors D1\u2013D4\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'number_resolving': True,\n  'single_emitters': [7],         # control photon\n  'removed_connections': [],      # allow standard pair\u2010source outputs\n  'in_nodes': [],                 \n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],     # metasurface outputs\n  'out_nodes': [#, remaining photons at the two entangled nodes] \n}\n\nThis target is a pure quantum\u2010network task\u2014no forbidden state generation\u2014enabling a novel triangular\u2010graph quantum SWITCH that Pytheus can optimize as a static linear\u2010optics + ancilla\u2010detector experiment with probabilistic sources.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This triangular\u2010network superposition of entanglement\u2010swap locations is effectively the same primitive as the ensemble\u2019s superposed perfect\u2010matching swaps (and the photonic quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swap proposals): it merely places swap operations into a coherent superposition of three edges. Overview & Roles  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 produces photons 1\u21942 (A\u2013B).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 produces photons 3\u21944 (B\u2013C).  \n \u2022 Control photon 5 (single-photon emitter) is prepared in |+\u27e9 and split into two spatial modes c\u2080, c\u2081 by a beam splitter.  \n \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes photon 5 into the subcircuit M\u2081\u2192M\u2082 (do A\u2013B swap then B\u2013C swap).  \n \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes photon 5 into M\u2082\u2192M\u2081 (do B\u2013C swap then A\u2013B swap).  \n\n2. Photonic-Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements fixed optical delays so that photons 1\u20135 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface inputs.  \n \u2022 Performs coarse wavelength demultiplexing if S\u2081, S\u2082 operate at slightly different \u03bb, and narrowband single-mode filtering to ensure high interference contrast.  \n\n3. Metasurface SWITCH Measurement  \n \u2022 A 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes the two Bell-pair halves from whichever order was chosen (photons 1 & 3 after the routing delays) together with control mode 5 and one vacuum ancilla.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2084.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 If D-click pattern p\u2080 occurs, the metasurface has enacted the SWITCH operation in the \u201cM\u2081\u2192M\u2082\u201d branch, coherently swapping entanglement A\u2013B then B\u2013C (yielding A\u2013C entangled).  \n   \u2013 If D-click pattern p\u2081 occurs, it enacted \u201cM\u2082\u2192M\u2081\u201d (B\u2013C then A\u2013B), also yielding A\u2013C entangled.  \n Thanks to the control-photon superposition, the two orders are in coherent superposition\u2014realizing an entanglement-swapping SWITCH in one static measurement.  \n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 First optical demonstration of a quantum SWITCH applied to entanglement swapping\u2014a fundamentally new network primitive where the causal order of two swap steps is in superposition.  \n \u2022 Combines two cutting-edge photonic platforms: metasurfaces for complex multi-photon unitaries and photonic crystals for integrated delay & spectral routing.  \n \u2022 Purely linear-optical, uses only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one single-photon control, static metasurface + ancilla detectors, and no feed-forward.  \n \u2022 Directly extensible to longer chains (one-shot multi-order SWITCH with N swap steps) or richer network topologies.  \n\n5. Pytheus Configuration Skeleton  \n{  \n  'description': 'Indefinite-Causal-Order Entanglement Swapping via Metasurface SWITCH',  \n  'foldername': 'ic_order_swap',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 40,  \n  'ftol': 1e-6,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 4,                   # detectors D1\u2013D4 at metasurface outputs  \n  'num_pre': 1,  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'imaginary': False,  \n  'safe_hist': True,  \n  'number_resolving': True,  \n  'single_emitters': [5],         # control photon  \n  'removed_connections': [],      # standard pair-source outputs allowed  \n  'in_nodes': [],                 # all sources feed the metasurface via photonic-crystal routing  \n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],     # D1\u2013D4  \n  'out_nodes': [0,4]              # final entangled photons at A (mode 0) and C (mode 4)  \n}\n\nThis is a pure quantum-network task\u2014no forbidden state generation\u2014and sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s regime of probabilistic pair sources, single-photon emitters, static linear optics, and post-selection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The core primitive\u2014placing two entanglement\u2010swap steps in a coherent superposition of orders to realize a quantum SWITCH for entanglement swapping\u2014has already been proposed in multiple ensemble suggestions (e.g., on\u2010chip indefinite\u2010order superchannel switch, photonic quantum SWITCH superactivates entanglement, and entanglement\u2010switch quantum switch). Butterfly Link  \n \u2022 The \u201cbottleneck\u201d link X\u2013Y in the middle carries two half-pairs (3 from S\u2081 and 4 from S\u2082).  \n \u2022 We consolidate those four modes (3,4 plus the two unknowns 0,1 after swapping out of X, Y) into one 6-mode metasurface measurement, implementing two Bell-measurements in network-coded fashion.\n\n3. Photonic-Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements on-chip fixed delays to synchronize modes 0\u20135 at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Performs wavelength-demultiplexing: qubit A uses \u03bb\u2081, qubit B uses \u03bb\u2082, Bell pairs S\u2081\u2013S\u2084 standardized at \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering & single-mode operation for high-visibility six-photon interference.\n\n4. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Here we fuse both Bell projections into a single static four-photon joint measurement implemented on an optical metasurface, and use a dielectric photonic-crystal network for on-chip delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive in phase.\n\nNodes & Photons:\n \u2022 Alice (A) holds photon 0 in an unknown qubit state |\u03c8\u27e9 (single-photon emitter) and photon 1 (half of Bell pair S\u2081).  \n \u2022 Repeater (B) holds photon 2 (the other half of S\u2081) and photon 3 (half of Bell pair S\u2082).  \n \u2022 Charlie (C) holds photon 4 (the other half of S\u2082).\n\nResources:\n \u2022 S\u2081 emits 1\u21942; S\u2082 emits 3\u21944 probabilistically.  \n \u2022 Photon 0 is the unknown input from a single-photon source.  \n \u2022 Photonic-crystal waveguides implement fixed delays and tight spectral filtering so that 0\u20133 arrive simultaneously onto the metasurface.\n\nMetasurface Measurement:\n \u2022 A 4-mode linear-optics network on an optical metasurface effects the two Bell projections (0\u22971 and 2\u22973) simultaneously as one joint measurement.  \n \u2022 Its four output modes feed number-resolving detectors. Network & Resources  \n \u2022 Nodes A, B, C form a triangle.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 on edge A\u2013B emits photons 1\u21942 at wavelength \u03bb\u2081.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 on B\u2013C emits photons 3\u21944 at \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2083 on C\u2013A emits photons 5\u21946 at \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Control photon 7 is prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter and split into a coherent superposition of three spatial arms |c\u2081\u27e9,|c\u2082\u27e9,|c\u2083\u27e9, routing it to A, B or C.\n\n2. Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements three\u2010way wavelength\u2010demultiplexing (\u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082,\u03bb\u2083), fixed on\u2010chip delays, and narrowband filtering so that the two photons of any chosen Bell pair and the control photon arrive simultaneously and indistinguishably at the metasurface inputs.\n\n3. Metasurface 4-Mode Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes (pair\u2010photon 1, pair\u2010photon 2) + control photon 7 + a vacuum ancilla.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 If the control path was c\u2081 (node A) and D-pattern p\u2081 clicks, the metasurface has effected a Bell\u2010measurement on photons 5&6 (edge C\u2013A), swapping entanglement to yield A\u2013B entangled.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2082 & pattern p\u2082, then B performs the swap on (1&2), entangling B\u2013C.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2083 & pattern p\u2083, then C swaps (3&4), entangling C\u2013A.  \n Because the control photon was in superposition, all three swap\u2010locations are coherently superposed, realizing a genuine triangular\u2010network quantum SWITCH.\n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 Introduces a new quantum\u2010network primitive: superposed choice of which node performs entanglement\u2010swap in a cycle.  \n \u2022 Combines two emerging photonic platforms\u2014metasurfaces for multi-photon unitary design and photonic crystals for passive routing/delay\u2014into a single network operation.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond line\u2010network causal superpositions to a loop topology with three alternatives.  \n \u2022 Extensible to larger graphs (e.g. squares, pentagons) by adding more Bell pairs, control photons, and metasurface ports.\n\n5. Pytheus Configuration Skeleton  \n{\n  'description': 'Superposed\u2010Node Swap on Triangle Network',\n  'foldername': 'triangle_superposition_swap',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,                   # detectors D1\u2013D4\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'number_resolving': True,\n  'single_emitters': [7],         # control photon\n  'removed_connections': [],      # allow standard pair\u2010source outputs\n  'in_nodes': [],                 \n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],     # metasurface outputs\n  'out_nodes': [#, remaining photons at the two entangled nodes] \n}\n\nThis target is a pure quantum\u2010network task\u2014no forbidden state generation\u2014enabling a novel triangular\u2010graph quantum SWITCH that Pytheus can optimize as a static linear\u2010optics + ancilla\u2010detector experiment with probabilistic sources.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core idea\u2014coherently superposing which entanglement\u2010swap is performed\u2014has already been covered by the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps\u201d and quantum\u2010switch proposals. Overview & Roles  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 produces photons 1\u21942 (A\u2013B).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 produces photons 3\u21944 (B\u2013C).  \n \u2022 Control photon 5 (single-photon emitter) is prepared in |+\u27e9 and split into two spatial modes c\u2080, c\u2081 by a beam splitter.  \n \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes photon 5 into the subcircuit M\u2081\u2192M\u2082 (do A\u2013B swap then B\u2013C swap).  \n \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes photon 5 into M\u2082\u2192M\u2081 (do B\u2013C swap then A\u2013B swap).  \n\n2. Network Topology & Roles  \n \u2022 Senders A and B each hold an unknown qubit in modes 0 and 1 (single-photon emitters).  \n \u2022 Four Bell-pair sources for the four edges:  \n   \u2013 S\u2081 (A\u2192X): photons 2\u21943  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 (B\u2192Y): photons 4\u21945  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 (X\u2192C): photons 6\u21947  \n   \u2013 S\u2084 (Y\u2192D): photons 8\u21949  \n \u2022 Receivers C and D hold photons 7 and 9 respectively.\n\n2. The Butterfly \u201cBottleneck\u201d  \n \u2022 The central link X\u2013Y must transmit two qubit channels (from A and B) simultaneously.  \n \u2022 We perform a single joint measurement on modes [0,1,3,4] (the two unknowns plus the two Bell-pairs halves at the bottleneck) to network-code the teleportations.\n\n3. Dielectric Photonic-Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Demultiplexes wavelengths: unknown qubit A in \u03bb\u2081, unknown qubit B in \u03bb\u2082, all Bell-pairs in \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Provides fixed on-chip delays so that modes 0,1,3,4 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Offers narrowband single-mode filtering to ensure high-visibility multi-photon interference.\n\n4. Metasurface Multiport Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 6-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes input modes [0,1,3,4] plus two vacuum ancilla ports.  \n \u2022 Six output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2086.  \n \u2022 Two distinct heralding patterns p\u2080 and p\u2081 correspond to two network-coded teleportation outcomes:  \n   \u2013 p\u2080 heralds qubit 0\u21927 and 1\u21929 (standard routing).  \n   \u2013 p\u2081 heralds qubit 0\u21929 and 1\u21927 (cross-routed coding).  \n \u2022 In both cases, receivers C and D end up each with one unknown qubit, and the shared central link is used only once, without sequential swaps or classical feed-forward.\n\n5.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Three-Node Entanglement Router Optimizing Genuine Tripartite Mutual Information\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a static photonic linear-optical network in Pytheus\u2014comprising three SPDC pair sources, a tunable three-mode interferometer, and heralding ancilla detectors\u2014to variationally extremize the genuine tripartite mutual information I\u2083(A;B;C) among remote modes A, B, and C. A classical optimizer adjusts interferometer phases to maximize (or minimize) I\u2083(A;B;C) as the sole cost function, thereby targeting non-trivial entanglement monogamy without prescribing any specific quantum state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Ancilla-Only Entanglement Swapping via a Discrete Squeezed-Reservoir\n\nAbstract: We introduce a purely network-level primitive in which two SPDC sources generate entangled pairs AB (modes 1\u20132) and BC (modes 3\u20134), and a third SPDC source at Bob produces a \u201csqueezed-reservoir\u201d Bell pair (modes 5\u20136) that is weakly coupled via beam splitters to Bob\u2019s system modes 2 and 3. By performing photon-counting only on the ancilla modes and conditioning on coincident clicks, Alice\u2019s and Charlie\u2019s remote modes 1 and 4 are projected onto the Bell state |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9\u2014effecting entanglement swapping without ever measuring Bob\u2019s system qubits and preserving local memory for subsequent quantum network operations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: On-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\n\nAbstract: We target the design of an integrated-photonic \u201csuperchannel switch\u201d that coherently superposes two distinct quantum network primitives\u2014entanglement swapping (ES) and quantum teleportation (QT)\u2014in indefinite causal order. By combining two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a single-photon input qubit and a control ancilla in a fixed linear-optical interferometer, we perform Bell-state measurements and post-select on \u201c+\u201d outcomes to herald a coherent superposition of the ES\u2192QT and QT\u2192ES sequences, all without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation of a Single-Photon Qubit through a Coherent Superposition of Markovian and Non-Markovian Channels\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose and analyze an optical teleportation experiment in which an unknown target qubit is split into two rails that interact with engineered ancilla chains\u2014one Markovian and one non-Markovian\u2014before being coherently recombined. A Bell-state measurement at Charlie, conditioned on specific click patterns, heralds the successful teleportation of the target quantum to Bob, with fidelity controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and memory-chain parameters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). End-to-end tomography at the chosen node measures the three projector outcomes specified for the selected entanglement witness (the explicit target quantum set), thereby certifying entanglement only in the routed branch.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nBoundary-Scaling Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer for Toric-Code Patches  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a static linear-optical circuit\u2014the Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer with Boundary-Scaling\u2014that simultaneously measures all four-body Z stabilizers of an arbitrary connected toric-code plaquette patch using a shared pool of ancilla photons, such that the total ancilla detectors (or photons) scale with the patch\u2019s perimeter rather than its area. By tuning the synthetic gauge\u2010flux phase \u03c6 on the CA beam splitter, we explicitly realize the Pyth eus target mapping\u2014|1,0,0\u27e9_ABC\u2192|0,1,0\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192B channel) at \u03c6=\u03c0 or |0,0,1\u27e9_ABC (A\u2192C channel) at \u03c6=0\u2014with high fidelity, thereby achieving topologically protected, nonreciprocal routing.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOn\u2010Chip Three\u2010Photon Repetition\u2010Code Logical\u2010Bell State Analyzer in Silicon Photonics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract:  \nWe propose and design an integrated silicon\u2010photonic circuit that implements an error\u2010detecting logical\u2010Bell state measurement on two qubits encoded in the three\u2010photon repetition code, using six waveguide modes, tunable Mach\u2013Zehnder interferometer parity\u2010check modules, and a final multiport interferometer. Heralding coincidences in M_Z versus M_X project the target remote nodes A and C onto \u03a6\u207a_Z or \u03a6\u207a_X respectively, and by scanning \u03c6 and performing two-qubit tomography we observe high-visibility fringes certifying a coherent superposition of distinct Bell-state swap bases beyond ordinary swapping or switching.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Reconfigurable Integrated Three-Photon GHZ-Basis Analyzer on Pytheus\n\nAbstract: We implement the target Pytheus-configurable three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer by injecting three unknown photonic qubits and an ancilla Bell pair into a fixed mesh of 50:50 beam splitters augmented with three on-chip electro-optic phase shifters and heralding detectors, thereby unambiguously mapping any incoming triple onto one of the four GHZ basis states. Conditioned on fourfold heralding of the ancilla detections, the remote signal modes at Alice and Bob collapse into the target two-photon Bell state |00\u3009+|11\u3009 despite originating from noisy channels, demonstrating a teleportation-style network implementation of coherent quantum noise cancellation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. A single specific detection pattern heralds that 0 has been teleported to 4 in Node C, without any intermediate feed-forward.\n\n\u2013 Roles of photonic crystals:\n  \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal network on chip implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive simultaneous and in the correct spatial modes onto the metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The photonic crystal also filters out spurious sidebands and ensures pure single-mode operation, critical for high\u2010fidelity multi-photon interference.\n\n\u2013 Why it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates fusing multiple entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one static joint measurement, reducing the need for active switching or classical communication.  \n  \u2022 Leverages metasurfaces for complex multi-photon projections and photonic crystals for integrated timing/control\u2014two rapidly advancing photonic platforms.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended: three-hop teleportation (six-photon joint measurement), star\u2010topologies, or network repeater nodes with higher fan-out.  \n\nThis target focuses on the quantum-network task of teleportation over two segments in one \u201cshot,\u201d avoiding forbidden state generation tasks, and is well matched to pytheus\u2019s ability to optimize linear-optics networks with probabilistic sources and ancilla detectors.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially the same target as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two-Hop Entanglement Swap in the A\u2013B_router\u2013C_router\u2013D Quantum Network,\u201d merging two successive Bell swaps into one four-photon joint measurement to teleport across two segments in one shot. Concept & Roles  \n \u2022 Bell\u2010pair S\u2081 emits photons 1\u21942.  \n \u2022 Bell\u2010pair S\u2082 emits photons 3\u21944.  \n \u2022 Control photon 5, prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter, is placed in an equal superposition of two spatial modes |0\u27e9\u2085 and |1\u27e9\u2085 via a beam splitter.  \n \u2022 Alice holds photons 1 and 3; Bob holds photons 2 and 4; the control photon goes to the central node E.\n\n2. Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements static delay lines so photons 1,3,5 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Performs narrowband demultiplexing (if sources operate at slightly offset wavelengths) and single\u2010mode filtering to guarantee high\u2010visibility interference.\n\n3. Metasurface Multiport Measurement at Node E  \n \u2022 A custom 3\u00d73 (plus vacuum ancilla inputs) linear\u2010optics network on an optical metasurface mixes modes 1,3,5.  \n \u2022 Modes 1 and 3 are the Bell\u2010pair halves; mode 5 is the control qubit.  \n \u2022 Three output modes feed number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081, D\u2082, D\u2083.  \n \u2022 Heralding condition: exactly one click in D\u2081\u2013D\u2083 and no other photons.  \n   \u2013 If detector outcome pattern p\u2080 occurs, the metasurface has enacted a \u201cstandard\u201d Bell\u2010projection on (1,3), entangling 2\u21944 (A\u2013D swap).  \n   \u2013 If pattern p\u2081 occurs, the metasurface has enacted a \u201ccrossed\u201d projection, entangling 2\u21943 and 1\u21944 (A\u2013C & B\u2013D swap).  \n   \u2013 Because the control photon was in superposition, the overall network implements a coherent quantum\u2010controlled swap\u2014realizing an indefinite routing of entanglement.\n\n4. Why It\u2019s New & Generalizable  \n \u2022 Demonstrates a quantum switch: the connectivity of the network (which qubits become entangled) is coherently controlled by a third photon, all in one static measurement.  \n \u2022 Exploits metasurfaces for complex, high\u2010order multi\u2010photon unitary design and photonic crystals for integrated delay and spectral routing.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond passive state generation into active network topology control in superposition.  \n \u2022 Scales to N\u2010way routing by adding more Bell pairs, control photons, and metasurface ports; explorations of quantum causal structures become possible.\n\n5. Resources & Routing  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 emits photons 1\u21942 (A\u2013B).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 emits photons 3\u21944 (B\u2013C).  \n \u2022 Control photon 5 (single-photon emitter) is prepared in |+\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2\u2192 splits by a 50:50 splitter into two spatial modes c\u2080,c\u2081.  \n \u2022 In path c\u2080 the metasurface\u2019s pre-circuit performs Bell measurement M\u2081 on (2,3) then M\u2082 on (output, vacuum)\u2014i.e. the \u201cBC first\u201d order.  \n \u2022 In path c\u2081 it performs M\u2082 on (2,3) then M\u2081\u2014i.e. the \u201cAB first\u201d order.  \n \u2022 A dielectric photonic-crystal chip supplies fixed on-chip delays, spectral demultiplexing (if S\u2081,S\u2082 use different \u03bb), and single-mode filtering so that both routes arrive indistinguishably at the metasurface input ports.\n\n2. Metasurface Joint Measurement  \n \u2022 A 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes the two swapped outputs plus the control modes.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2084.  \n \u2022 A specific click pattern p heralds that A and C are now entangled, and the control photon\u2019s interference ensures that the two orders \u201cM\u2081\u2192M\u2082\u201d and \u201cM\u2082\u2192M\u2081\u201d were in coherent superposition\u2014implementing indefinite causal order.  \n\n3. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 First optical demonstration of a quantum SWITCH in an entanglement-swapping network.  \n \u2022 Leverages photonic crystals for passive timing/spectral routing and metasurfaces for high-order multi-photon measurement.  \n \u2022 Shows a new network primitive: superposed connection order in a repeater node, which may enhance average fidelity or open new causal-order\u2013based protocols.  \n \u2022 Extendable to longer chains (one-shot N-order superposition) or star networks with multiple swap orders.\n\nPytheus Configuration Skeleton:\n{\n  'description': 'Indefinite-Causal-Order Entanglement Swapping via Metasurface',\n  'foldername': 'ic_order_swap',\n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,\n  'edges_tried': 40,\n  'ftol': 1e-6,\n  'loss_func': 'cr',\n  'num_anc': 4,                     # detectors D1\u2013D4 at metasurface outputs\n  'num_pre': 1,\n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',\n  'samples': 20,\n  'imaginary': False,\n  'safe_hist': True,\n  'number_resolving': True,\n  'single_emitters': [5],           # control photon\n  'removed_connections': [],        # allow standard pair-source routing\n  'in_nodes': [],                   \n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3],       # D1,D2,D3,D4\n  'out_nodes': [0,4]                # photons at A (mode\u20090) and C (mode\u20094)\n}\n\nThis target is a pure quantum-network primitive\u2014indefinite-causal-order entanglement swapping\u2014realized by static linear optics, probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one control emitter, a metasurface measurement and photonic-crystal routing. Network & Resources  \n \u2022 Nodes A, B, C form a triangle.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 on edge A\u2013B emits photons 1\u21942 at wavelength \u03bb\u2081.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 on B\u2013C emits photons 3\u21944 at \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2083 on C\u2013A emits photons 5\u21946 at \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Control photon 7 is prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter and split into a coherent superposition of three spatial arms |c\u2081\u27e9,|c\u2082\u27e9,|c\u2083\u27e9, routing it to A, B or C.\n\n2. Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements three\u2010way wavelength\u2010demultiplexing (\u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082,\u03bb\u2083), fixed on\u2010chip delays, and narrowband filtering so that the two photons of any chosen Bell pair and the control photon arrive simultaneously and indistinguishably at the metasurface inputs.\n\n3. Metasurface 4-Mode Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes (pair\u2010photon 1, pair\u2010photon 2) + control photon 7 + a vacuum ancilla.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 If the control path was c\u2081 (node A) and D-pattern p\u2081 clicks, the metasurface has effected a Bell\u2010measurement on photons 5&6 (edge C\u2013A), swapping entanglement to yield A\u2013B entangled.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2082 & pattern p\u2082, then B performs the swap on (1&2), entangling B\u2013C.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2083 & pattern p\u2083, then C swaps (3&4), entangling C\u2013A.  \n Because the control photon was in superposition, all three swap\u2010locations are coherently superposed, realizing a genuine triangular\u2010network quantum SWITCH.\n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 Introduces a new quantum\u2010network primitive: superposed choice of which node performs entanglement\u2010swap in a cycle.  \n \u2022 Combines two emerging photonic platforms\u2014metasurfaces for multi-photon unitary design and photonic crystals for passive routing/delay\u2014into a single network operation.  \n \u2022 Goes beyond line\u2010network causal superpositions to a loop topology with three alternatives.  \n \u2022 Extensible to larger graphs (e.g. squares, pentagons) by adding more Bell pairs, control photons, and metasurface ports.\n\n5. Overview & Roles  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 produces photons 1\u21942 (A\u2013B).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 produces photons 3\u21944 (B\u2013C).  \n \u2022 Control photon 5 (single-photon emitter) is prepared in |+\u27e9 and split into two spatial modes c\u2080, c\u2081 by a beam splitter.  \n \u2022 Path c\u2080 routes photon 5 into the subcircuit M\u2081\u2192M\u2082 (do A\u2013B swap then B\u2013C swap).  \n \u2022 Path c\u2081 routes photon 5 into M\u2082\u2192M\u2081 (do B\u2013C swap then A\u2013B swap).  \n\n2. Photonic-Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements fixed optical delays so that photons 1\u20135 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface inputs.  \n \u2022 Performs coarse wavelength demultiplexing if S\u2081, S\u2082 operate at slightly different \u03bb, and narrowband single-mode filtering to ensure high interference contrast.  \n\n3. Metasurface SWITCH Measurement  \n \u2022 A 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes the two Bell-pair halves from whichever order was chosen (photons 1 & 3 after the routing delays) together with control mode 5 and one vacuum ancilla.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2084.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 If D-click pattern p\u2080 occurs, the metasurface has enacted the SWITCH operation in the \u201cM\u2081\u2192M\u2082\u201d branch, coherently swapping entanglement A\u2013B then B\u2013C (yielding A\u2013C entangled).  \n   \u2013 If D-click pattern p\u2081 occurs, it enacted \u201cM\u2082\u2192M\u2081\u201d (B\u2013C then A\u2013B), also yielding A\u2013C entangled.  \n Thanks to the control-photon superposition, the two orders are in coherent superposition\u2014realizing an entanglement-swapping SWITCH in one static measurement.  \n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 First optical demonstration of a quantum SWITCH applied to entanglement swapping\u2014a fundamentally new network primitive where the causal order of two swap steps is in superposition.  \n \u2022 Combines two cutting-edge photonic platforms: metasurfaces for complex multi-photon unitaries and photonic crystals for integrated delay & spectral routing.  \n \u2022 Purely linear-optical, uses only probabilistic Bell-pair sources, one single-photon control, static metasurface + ancilla detectors, and no feed-forward.  \n \u2022 Directly extensible to longer chains (one-shot multi-order SWITCH with N swap steps) or richer network topologies.  \n\n5. Topology & Roles  \n \u2022 Senders A, B each hold an unknown qubit from single-photon emitters (modes 0 and 1).  \n \u2022 Four Bell pairs:  \n   \u2013 S\u2081 (A\u2192X): photons 2\u21943  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 (B\u2192Y): photons 4\u21945  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 (X\u2192C): photons 6\u21947  \n   \u2013 S\u2084 (Y\u2192D): photons 8\u21949  \n \u2022 Receiver C holds photon 7; receiver D holds photon 9.\n\n2. Butterfly Link  \n \u2022 The \u201cbottleneck\u201d link X\u2013Y in the middle carries two half-pairs (3 from S\u2081 and 4 from S\u2082).  \n \u2022 We consolidate those four modes (3,4 plus the two unknowns 0,1 after swapping out of X, Y) into one 6-mode metasurface measurement, implementing two Bell-measurements in network-coded fashion.\n\n3. Photonic-Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements on-chip fixed delays to synchronize modes 0\u20135 at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Performs wavelength-demultiplexing: qubit A uses \u03bb\u2081, qubit B uses \u03bb\u2082, Bell pairs S\u2081\u2013S\u2084 standardized at \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Provides narrowband filtering & single-mode operation for high-visibility six-photon interference.\n\n4. Metasurface Multiport Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 6\u00d76 static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes input modes [0,1,3,4, vacuum, vacuum].  \n \u2022 Six outputs feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2013D\u2086.  \n \u2022 Two distinct four-click patterns herald:  \n   \u2013 Pattern p\u2080: teleportation of qubit 0\u21927 and 1\u21929 (the \u201cstandard\u201d encoded routing),  \n   \u2013 Pattern p\u2081: cross-routed teleportation 0\u21929 and 1\u21927 (the network-coded routing).  \n \u2022 In both cases C and D end up each with one unknown qubit, but the metasurface network coding allows simultaneous use of the central link without feed-forward.\n\n5. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 First demonstration of quantum network coding in a photonic butterfly network using linear optics.  \n \u2022 Showcases metasurfaces for high-order multi-photon joint measurements and photonic crystals for integrated wavelength routing & delay.  \n \u2022 Eliminates sequential swapping and classical communication; implements two teleportations through a shared link in one static measurement.  \n \u2022 Extendable to larger network coding topologies (e.g. multi-cast, n-sender m-receiver codes) by scaling metasurface size and adding spectral channels.\n\n6. Network Topology & Roles  \n \u2022 Senders A and B each hold an unknown qubit in modes 0 and 1 (single-photon emitters).  \n \u2022 Four Bell-pair sources for the four edges:  \n   \u2013 S\u2081 (A\u2192X): photons 2\u21943  \n   \u2013 S\u2082 (B\u2192Y): photons 4\u21945  \n   \u2013 S\u2083 (X\u2192C): photons 6\u21947  \n   \u2013 S\u2084 (Y\u2192D): photons 8\u21949  \n \u2022 Receivers C and D hold photons 7 and 9 respectively.\n\n2. The Butterfly \u201cBottleneck\u201d  \n \u2022 The central link X\u2013Y must transmit two qubit channels (from A and B) simultaneously.  \n \u2022 We perform a single joint measurement on modes [0,1,3,4] (the two unknowns plus the two Bell-pairs halves at the bottleneck) to network-code the teleportations.\n\n3. Dielectric Photonic-Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Demultiplexes wavelengths: unknown qubit A in \u03bb\u2081, unknown qubit B in \u03bb\u2082, all Bell-pairs in \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Provides fixed on-chip delays so that modes 0,1,3,4 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Offers narrowband single-mode filtering to ensure high-visibility multi-photon interference.\n\n4. Metasurface Multiport Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 6-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes input modes [0,1,3,4] plus two vacuum ancilla ports.  \n \u2022 Six output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2086.  \n \u2022 Two distinct heralding patterns p\u2080 and p\u2081 correspond to two network-coded teleportation outcomes:  \n   \u2013 p\u2080 heralds qubit 0\u21927 and 1\u21929 (standard routing).  \n   \u2013 p\u2081 heralds qubit 0\u21929 and 1\u21927 (cross-routed coding).  \n \u2022 In both cases, receivers C and D end up each with one unknown qubit, and the shared central link is used only once, without sequential swaps or classical feed-forward.\n\n5. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 First realization of quantum network coding in optics for the butterfly network using a single static joint measurement.  \n \u2022 Leverages optical metasurfaces for high-order multi-photon unitaries and photonic crystals for integrated spectral routing and timing.  \n \u2022 Eliminates sequential entanglement swapping and active switching; executes two teleportations through a congested link in one shot.  \n \u2022 Directly extensible to larger network-coding topologies (e.g. multiple senders/receivers) by scaling the metasurface size and adding spectral channels on the photonic-crystal chip.\n\n6. A single specific detection pattern heralds that 0 has been teleported to 4 in Node C, without any intermediate feed-forward.\n\n\u2013 Roles of photonic crystals:\n  \u2022 A dielectric photonic\u2010crystal network on chip implements static delay lines and wavelength-selective routing so that all four photons arrive simultaneous and in the correct spatial modes onto the metasurface.  \n  \u2022 The photonic crystal also filters out spurious sidebands and ensures pure single-mode operation, critical for high\u2010fidelity multi-photon interference.\n\n\u2013 Why it\u2019s interesting & generalizable:\n  \u2022 Demonstrates fusing multiple entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one static joint measurement, reducing the need for active switching or classical communication.  \n  \u2022 Leverages metasurfaces for complex multi-photon projections and photonic crystals for integrated timing/control\u2014two rapidly advancing photonic platforms.  \n  \u2022 Can be extended: three-hop teleportation (six-photon joint measurement), star\u2010topologies, or network repeater nodes with higher fan-out.  \n\nThis target focuses on the quantum-network task of teleportation over two segments in one \u201cshot,\u201d avoiding forbidden state generation tasks, and is well matched to pytheus\u2019s ability to optimize linear-optics networks with probabilistic sources and ancilla detectors.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The core idea of compressing two sequential Bell measurements into a single four-photon joint measurement for two-hop teleportation has already been proposed and must be substantively extended (e.g. by adding a genuinely new causal structure, higher-order topological feature, or novel resource type) to be considered for PRL.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! A promising direction is to implement an all\u2010linear\u2010optics \u201cquantum switch\u201d that coherently controls the entanglement\u2010swapping topology\u2014i.e. places the network\u2019s wiring in a quantum superposition. By encoding the switch control in an extra single photon and performing a joint measurement on two Bell\u2010pair halves plus that control photon in a metasurface multiport, we can herald two distinct connectivity patterns (direct swap vs. crossed\u2010swap) or even a superposition of them, without any dynamic feed\u2010forward. A photonic\u2010crystal chip provides on\u2010chip delay, wavelength routing and narrowband filtering so that all photons arrive indistinguishably at the metasurface. Concept & Roles  \n \u2022 Bell\u2010pair S\u2081 emits photons 1\u21942.  \n \u2022 Bell\u2010pair S\u2082 emits photons 3\u21944.  \n \u2022 Control photon 5, prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter, is placed in an equal superposition of two spatial modes |0\u27e9\u2085 and |1\u27e9\u2085 via a beam splitter.  \n \u2022 Alice holds photons 1 and 3; Bob holds photons 2 and 4; the control photon goes to the central node E.\n\n2. Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements static delay lines so photons 1,3,5 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Performs narrowband demultiplexing (if sources operate at slightly offset wavelengths) and single\u2010mode filtering to guarantee high\u2010visibility interference.\n\n3. Metasurface Multiport Measurement at Node E  \n \u2022 A custom 3\u00d73 (plus vacuum ancilla inputs) linear\u2010optics network on an optical metasurface mixes modes 1,3,5.  \n \u2022 Modes 1 and 3 are the Bell\u2010pair halves; mode 5 is the control qubit.  \n \u2022 Three output modes feed number\u2010resolving detectors D\u2081, D\u2082, D\u2083.  \n \u2022 Heralding condition: exactly one click in D\u2081\u2013D\u2083 and no other photons.  \n   \u2013 If detector outcome pattern p\u2080 occurs, the metasurface has enacted a \u201cstandard\u201d Bell\u2010projection on (1,3), entangling 2\u21944 (A\u2013D swap).  \n   \u2013 If pattern p\u2081 occurs, the metasurface has enacted a \u201ccrossed\u201d projection, entangling 2\u21943 and 1\u21944 (A\u2013C & B\u2013D swap).  \n   \u2013 Because the control photon was in superposition, the overall network implements a coherent quantum\u2010controlled swap\u2014realizing an indefinite routing of entanglement.\n\n4. Why It\u2019s New & Generalizable  \n \u2022 Demonstrates a quantum switch: the connectivity of the network (which qubits become entangled) is coherently controlled by a third photon, all in one static measurement.  \n \u2022 Exploits metasurfaces for complex, high\u2010order multi\u2010photon unitary design and photonic crystals for integrated delay and spectral routing.  \n \u2022 Moves beyond passive state generation into active network topology control in superposition.  \n \u2022 Scales to N\u2010way routing by adding more Bell pairs, control photons, and metasurface ports; explorations of quantum causal structures become possible.\n\n5. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Resources & Routing  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 emits photons 1\u21942 (A\u2013B).  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 emits photons 3\u21944 (B\u2013C).  \n \u2022 Control photon 5 (single-photon emitter) is prepared in |+\u27e9=(|0\u27e9+|1\u27e9)/\u221a2\u2192 splits by a 50:50 splitter into two spatial modes c\u2080,c\u2081.  \n \u2022 In path c\u2080 the metasurface\u2019s pre-circuit performs Bell measurement M\u2081 on (2,3) then M\u2082 on (output, vacuum)\u2014i.e. the \u201cBC first\u201d order.  \n \u2022 In path c\u2081 it performs M\u2082 on (2,3) then M\u2081\u2014i.e. the \u201cAB first\u201d order.  \n \u2022 A dielectric photonic-crystal chip supplies fixed on-chip delays, spectral demultiplexing (if S\u2081,S\u2082 use different \u03bb), and single-mode filtering so that both routes arrive indistinguishably at the metasurface input ports.\n\n2. Network & Resources  \n \u2022 Nodes A, B, C form a triangle.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2081 on edge A\u2013B emits photons 1\u21942 at wavelength \u03bb\u2081.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2082 on B\u2013C emits photons 3\u21944 at \u03bb\u2082.  \n \u2022 Bell pair S\u2083 on C\u2013A emits photons 5\u21946 at \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Control photon 7 is prepared by a single\u2010photon emitter and split into a coherent superposition of three spatial arms |c\u2081\u27e9,|c\u2082\u27e9,|c\u2083\u27e9, routing it to A, B or C.\n\n2. Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements three\u2010way wavelength\u2010demultiplexing (\u03bb\u2081,\u03bb\u2082,\u03bb\u2083), fixed on\u2010chip delays, and narrowband filtering so that the two photons of any chosen Bell pair and the control photon arrive simultaneously and indistinguishably at the metasurface inputs.\n\n3. Metasurface 4-Mode Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 4-mode static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes (pair\u2010photon 1, pair\u2010photon 2) + control photon 7 + a vacuum ancilla.  \n \u2022 Four output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2084.  \n \u2022 Heralding patterns:  \n   \u2013 If the control path was c\u2081 (node A) and D-pattern p\u2081 clicks, the metasurface has effected a Bell\u2010measurement on photons 5&6 (edge C\u2013A), swapping entanglement to yield A\u2013B entangled.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2082 & pattern p\u2082, then B performs the swap on (1&2), entangling B\u2013C.  \n   \u2013 If c\u2083 & pattern p\u2083, then C swaps (3&4), entangling C\u2013A.  \n Because the control photon was in superposition, all three swap\u2010locations are coherently superposed, realizing a genuine triangular\u2010network quantum SWITCH.\n\n4.     "output": "We propose \u201cQuantum Network\u2010Coding Teleportation in the Butterfly Topology via a Metasurface Multiport and Photonic\u2010Crystal Routing.\u201d\n\n1. Task & Topology  \n \u2022 Two senders A, B each hold an unknown qubit (modes 0 and 1).  \n \u2022 Four Bell\u2010pair sources on edges:  \n     S\u2081: A\u2192X emits 2\u21943  \n     S\u2082: B\u2192Y emits 4\u21945  \n     S\u2083: X\u2192C emits 6\u21947  \n     S\u2084: Y\u2192D emits 8\u21949  \n \u2022 Receivers C, D hold photons 7 and 9.\n\nThe central link X\u2013Y is a bottleneck: we must teleport both qubits through it simultaneously.\n\n2. Dielectric Photonic\u2010Crystal Chip  \n \u2022 Implements fixed on\u2010chip delays so that modes 0,1,3,4 arrive simultaneously at the metasurface.  \n \u2022 Performs coarse wavelength\u2010demultiplexing: qubit A in \u03bb\u2081, qubit B in \u03bb\u2082, all Bell pairs in \u03bb\u2083.  \n \u2022 Provides narrowband single\u2010mode filtering to ensure high\u2010visibility multi\u2010photon interference.\n\n3. Metasurface 6-Mode Measurement  \n \u2022 A custom 6\u00d76 static linear-optics network on an optical metasurface mixes inputs [0,1,3,4] plus two vacuum ancilla ports.  \n \u2022 Six output modes feed number-resolving detectors D\u2081\u2026D\u2086.  \n \u2022 Two heralding patterns {p\u2080,p\u2081} correspond to two coding outcomes:  \n     \u2013 p\u2080 \u2192 teleport qubit 0\u21927 and 1\u21929 (standard routing)  \n     \u2013 p\u2081 \u2192 teleport 0\u21929 and 1\u21927 (cross\u2010routed \u201cnetwork\u2010coded\u201d teleportation)  \n \u2022 Both receivers end up each holding one qubit, and the central link is used only once, with a single static measurement\u2014no dynamic feed\u2010forward.\n\n4. Why It\u2019s Interesting & Generalizable  \n \u2022 First all-optical demo of quantum network coding (butterfly) via a single high-order metasurface measurement.  \n \u2022 Merges two cutting-edge photonic platforms: metasurfaces for complex multi-photon unitaries; photonic crystals for integrated delay, demux/mux and filtering.  \n \u2022 Eliminates sequential swaps and classical communication: two teleportations through a congested link in one shot.  \n \u2022 Directly extensible to larger sender/receiver codes by scaling the metasurface and adding spectral channels on the photonic-crystal chip.\n\n5. Pytheus Configuration Skeleton  \n{  \n  'description': 'Butterfly Network-Coding Teleportation via Metasurface & Photonic Crystal',  \n  'foldername': 'butterfly_qnc',  \n  'bulk_thr': 0.01,  \n  'edges_tried': 50,  \n  'ftol': 1e-6,  \n  'loss_func': 'cr',  \n  'num_anc': 6,                      # detectors D1\u2013D6 at metasurface outputs  \n  'num_pre': 1,  \n  'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B',  \n  'samples': 20,  \n  'imaginary': False,  \n  'safe_hist': True,  \n  'number_resolving': True,  \n  'single_emitters': [0,1],          # senders\u2019 unknown qubits  \n  'removed_connections': [],         # allow standard pair\u2010source outputs  \n  'in_nodes': [],                    # all sources feed metasurface via photonic crystal  \n  'anc_detectors': [0,1,2,3,4,5],    # D1\u2013D6  \n  'out_nodes': [7,9]                 # final qubits at C and D  \n}\n\nThis is purely a quantum-network experiment\u2014no forbidden state generation\u2014and fits Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (probabilistic Bell pairs, single-photon emitters, static linear optics, post\u2010selection). It opens a new direction in optical quantum networking by demonstrating network coding in a highly congested butterfly link using one static metasurface measurement and photonic\u2010crystal routing."
